headline: Lululemon partners with NFL to release apparel collection
summary: STORY: Lululemon Athletica scored a major deal with the NFL, sending its shares up nearly 5% in Monday morning trading.The yogawear maker said the collection, available starting Tuesday, will feature men's and women's apparel and accessories covering all 32 NFL teams.The collaboration marks the first time Lululemon has offered officially licensed products for the NFL or any of its teams. The Wall Street Journal reported the new product line will be promoted through a brand campaign featuring NFL figures such as Joe Montana, Nick Foles, Ryan Clark and Emmanuel Acho.Once a trailblazer in athletic wear, Lululemon has struggled in recent months.The company in September slashed its annual profit forecast for the second quarter in a row, blaming weak U.S. business and product issues, as well as tariff costs.Even with Monday's jump, shares of Lululemon are still down more than 50% so far this year.

headline: Why Lululemon (LULU) Stock Is Trading Up Today
summary: Shares of athletic apparel retailer Lululemon (NASDAQ:LULU) jumped 3% in the afternoon session after the company announced a new partnership with the National Football League (NFL) and sports merchandiser Fanatics to launch a collection of officially licensed apparel.

headline: Lululemon Pushes Further Into Pro Sports With NFL Deal. The Stock Is Up.
summary: Lululemon  Athletica stock took off in response to news that the company, best known for yoga gear, said it would be launching an apparel collection with products for all 32 National Football League teams.  This is the first time Lululemon is making officially licensed products for the NFL or any of its teams.  The company has an existing partnership with the National Hockey League.

headline: Yoga Pants, Oil and Pickup Trucks—These Companies Count on Canada
summary: For some of the U.S.'s biggest publicly traded companies, a deepening trade war with Canada poses a real financial risk.  Exxon Mobil and Ford Motor are among more than a dozen big publicly traded companies that generated at least 5% of sales from the U.S.'s northern neighbor in their most recent fiscal years.
